book_name: An Elegant Puzzle - Systems of Engineering Management - by Will Larson.pdf
summary: In this chapter, the focus is on understanding the gaps in one's role and how to effectively delegate responsibilities. It encourages individuals to reflect on their unique skills and actions that complement their colleagues' work. By auditing communication and to-do lists, leaders can identify tasks that can be delegated or refined. The chapter emphasizes developing a structured plan for closing these gaps, distinguishing between easy and riskier tasks. This exercise is not only a strategic approach to succession planning but also fosters personal growth and organizational resilience.

slides.section_body: Reflect on the areas where your skills complement those of your colleagues. Think about what people rely on you for, whether it’s guidance, technical expertise, or organizational navigation. This understanding is key to maximizing teamwork and efficiency.
slides.quote: Your unique contribution is the foundation of effective collaboration.

slides.section_body: Review inbound chats and emails to identify the key requests and questions coming your way. This audit will highlight the areas where you are most engaged and can pinpoint possible gaps in responsibilities.
slides.quote: Awareness of communication reveals the true nature of your role.

slides.section_body: Look back over the last six months of completed tasks and ongoing projects. Understanding what you’ve done—and what you’ve delayed—will help you see where delegation can occur for smoother operations.
slides.quote: Past work is a mirror that reflects future potential.

slides.section_body: Identify key stakeholders and strategic partners crucial to your role. Understanding these relationships enhances your ability to delegate effectively and close gaps within your team.
slides.quote: Networking is a vital tool in the art of delegation.

slides.section_body: Create a detailed list of tasks and responsibilities identified during your audit. Share this with trusted colleagues to ensure you haven’t overlooked any important areas for delegation.
slides.quote: Collaboration in understanding helps clarify the path forward.

slides.section_body: For each responsibility on the list, determine if someone is readily available to take it over. Crossing off these items clarifies your current workload and highlights areas still in need of attention.
Filter your list to focus initially on the easiest gaps to close—those that require minimal effort or time. Aim to take action that can be completed swiftly to gain momentum.
slides.quote: Small wins pave the way for larger achievements.

slides.section_body: Next, identify the riskiest gaps—those areas where your unique skills are integral. Develop a strategy for these that involves ongoing effort to ensure they are addressed properly.
slides.quote: Risk often accompanies the most impactful changes.

slides.section_body: Draft a structured plan for addressing both the easy and risky gaps. Include these objectives in your personal growth goals, transforming delegation into an ongoing practice of improvement.
slides.quote: A plan gives structure to ambition.

slides.section_body: Closing gaps isn’t a singular event but a practice to revisit annually. This keeps your delegation skills sharp and allows for continuous growth in your role.
